Award.AwardTitle: NUE: NanoTRA- Texas Regional Alliance to foster 'Nanotechnology Environment, Health, and Safety Awareness' in tomorrow's Engineering and Technology Leaders

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program entitled, "NUE: NanoTRA-Texas Regional Alliance to foster 'Nanotechnology Environment, Health, and Safety Awareness' in tomorrow's Engineering and Technology Leaders", at Texas State University-San Marcos, under the direction of Dr. Jitendra S. Tate, will be a collaborative project with the University of Texas (UT) at Tyler, to develop introductory and advanced curricula that address the 'nanotechnology safety issues' that include social, ethical, environmental, health, and safety issues of nanotechnology. The curricula will be modular in nature, suitable for use either as two full semester courses that will be taught online at UT at Tyler or for insertion as separate modules into undergraduate engineering, engineering technology, and industrial technology courses at Texas State.

This project will initially impact more than 1,000 undergraduate engineering and technology students at Texas State and UT at Tyler, of which 350 are underrepresented minority students. The insights gained from the development of the courses and the rigorous assesment of learning outcomes will provide the basis for the inclusion of nanotechnology social, ethical, environmental, health, and safety issues in conventional engineering, engineering technology, industrial technology, and science courses. The experience gained from co-developing nanotechnology courses for two institutions will permit the replication of the courses at other institutions, including HBCUs and HSIs and community colleges, becoming a catalyst to promote nanotechnology safety education in two and four year institutions throughout the U.S. The development effort will enhance the qualifications of undergraduates, many of them women and Hispanics, as they pursue nanoscience and nanotechnology-related careers in industry or academia. The proposed project will help prepare a diverse workforce to supply the needs of emerging nanotechnology companies, over 100 of which are currently based in Texas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
‘NanoTRA ?Texas Regional Alliance to Foster Nanotechnology Environment, Health, and Safety Awareness in Tomorrow’s engineering and Technology Leaders’ project was funded by NSF under the program Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) for the period of 1/1/2013-12/31/2015.

Due to explosive growth in nanotechnology, a dramatically increasing number of engineers and technologists will be involved in the manufacturing of nanomaterials and in the design, development, and manufacturing of products, devices, and systems that use nanomaterials. Tomorrow’s engineers and technologists will need to assume responsibility for establishing safe and ethical practices for working with nanomaterials and for safeguarding the environment.

In the absence of specialized training in issues related to health, safety, and environmental impacts of nanotechnology, the tendency will be either to focus only on optimizing performance and cost while incorporating nanomaterials without regard to health and safety concerns, or to be overly cautious and avoid using nanotechnology. Therefore, in order to realize the full potential of revolutionary nanotechnologies and at the same time minimize undesirable consequences, engineers and technologists need to be educated in how to judge health and safety risks, how to weigh ethical considerations, and how to make informed decisions.

This project successfully trained undergraduate engineering and technology students early on in their career in nanotechnology safety issues so that they will fully exploit revolutionary nanotechnology for the benefit of society in their professional career. Students were educated in how to judge health and safety risks, how to weigh ethical considerations, and how to make informed decisions. During three year period of the project, more than 1600 undergraduate students were impacted at Texas State University and the University of Texas at Tyler. Significant percentage of these students (almost 35%) was minority students representing Hispanic, African American, and female.

Total 16 modules pertaining to environment, health, safety and ethical issues were developed at two different levels introductory and advanced.  Multidisciplinary team of seven investigators was actively involved in the development of these modules. Team represented fields of mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, industrial technology, physics, biology and philosophy. Nanotechnology Advisory Council (NAC) was established to guide this project. NAC members were accomplished professionals from academia, industry, and government agencies. Modules were revised as per the feedback of NAC, students, and external reviewer.

The project effectively used the model of infusing appropriate modules in existing courses at Texas State whereas full courses (introductory and advanced) were offered at the UT at Tyler. A variety of teaching methods to engage students, particularly women and Hispanic students were employed, including hands-on training, socially relevant case studies, plant tours, videos and guest lecturers. Introductory and advanced courses are being taught as online courses at the UT at Tyler. These online courses are available to anybody who is interested in learning about nanotechnology, in general and nanotechnology safety, in particular. The module presentations are available to all stakeholders of nanotechnology academia, industry, government agencies, policy makers and general public, upon request. Many faculty from engineering and technology programs at other universities considered infusing nanotechnology safety modules into their curriculum and have approached to project investigators.
